isaInvestigation.title: Investigation
isaInvestigation.description: Created using the MetaboLights Online Editor (MOE)

studies.title: Chlorophyll biosynthesis under the control of arginine metabolism.
studies.description: In natural environments, photosynthetic organisms adjust their metabolism to cope with the fluctuating availability of combined nitrogen sources, a growth-limiting factor. For acclimation, the dynamic degradation/synthesis of tetrapyrrolic pigments, as well as of the amino acid arginine, is pivotal; however, there has been no evidence that these processes could be functionally coupled. Using co-immunopurification and spectral shift assays, we found that in the cyanobacterium Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803, the arginine metabolism-related ArgD and CphB enzymes form protein complexes with Gun4, an essential protein for chlorophyll biosynthesis. Gun4 binds ArgD with high affinity, and the Gun4-ArgD complex accumulates in cells supplemented with ornithine, a key intermediate of the arginine pathway. Elevated ornithine levels restricted de novo synthesis of tetrapyrroles, which arrested the recovery from nitrogen deficiency. Our data reveal a direct crosstalk between tetrapyrrole biosynthesis and arginine metabolism that highlights the importance of balancing photosynthetic pigment synthesis with nitrogen homeostasis.

publications.title: Chlorophyll biosynthesis under the control of arginine metabolism
publications.authorList: Kiss Éva, Talbot Jana, Adams Nathan B.P., Opekar Stanislav, Moos Martin, Pilný Jan, Kvasov Tatjana, Schneider Emilia, Koník Peter, Šimek Petr, Sobotka Roman

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
Experimental model and subject details

Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 substrain GT-P[1] was used as the wild type (WT) and as a genetic background for all prepared strains listed in Table S1 in the paper associated with this study. Unless stated otherwise the Synechocystis strains were grown photoautotrophically in liquid BG-11 medium on a rotary shaker at 28 °C, under continuous, moderate irradiance of 40 µmol photons/m^2/s given by white fluorescence tubes. The plate-drop experiments were performed by pipetting liquid cultures on a BG-11 agar plate. The drops were photographed after 3 days of photoautotrophic growth at 30 °C, under constant illumination with 30 µmol photons/m^2/s. Alternatively, the plates were exposed to 500 µmol photons/m^2/s (high light); or to repeated periods of 5 min illumination with high light and 5 min dark (fluctuating light). The fluctuating nitrogen (N) stress was mimicked by repeated cycles of washing the cells to nitrate-less BG-11 (N0) for 8 h, followed by the addition of 18 mM NaNO3 supplement to the liquid cultures for another 8 h, while agitating at 240 rpm and 28 °C, illuminated by 200 µmol/m^2/s. When amino acids were included to the media the stable pH was ensured by 10 mM TES. The absorption spectra of cells were measured by a UV-3000 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu). The number and average size of cells were assessed by coulter counter (Multisizer 4, Beckman Coulter).


Construction of the Synechocystis model strains

The ΔargD and ΔcphB strains were constructed by replacing the slr1022 and slr2001 genes by erythromycin or spectinomycin resistance cassettes, respectively. The primers in the megaprimer PCR method used for mutagenesis are listed in Table S5 of the paper associated with the study. The segregation of ΔargD locus was achieved in the presence of 5 mM Orn. For the construction of strains expressing the N-terminally 3xFLAG-tagged ArgD protein (f.ArgD), we purchased a synthetic Synechocystis argD gene (GenScript, USA) with an optimized codon usage to remove the common restriction binding sites. To express the AstC enzyme from Escherichia coli (E.coli) in Synechocystis, the astC gene of E.coli was amplified by PCR from the genomic DNA. The argD and astC genes were cloned to the pPD-NFLAG plasmid[2][3]. The obtained constructs were transformed into Synechocystis ΔargD and/or ΔcphB cells. All transformed Synechocystis cells were fully segregated on BG-11 plates with increasing concentrations of relevant antibodies.


The phenotype of studied strains after feeding with biosynthetic intermediates of Arg was monitored. For this, using metabolic profiling, we checked the ability of Synechocystis to uptake N-acetylornithine (AcOrn), the enzymatic product of ArgD, treating WT with 100 μM AcOrn or 100 μM Orn, for 40 min.


Quantification of selected metabolites

For the quantification of selected metabolites by combined GC-MS and LC-MS analysis[4], 3 x 10^9 cells were collected by centrifugation and frozen in liquid N2.


Refs:

[1] Tichý M, Bečková M, Kopečná J, Noda J, Sobotka R, Komenda J. Strain of Synechocystis PCC 6803 with Aberrant Assembly of Photosystem II Contains Tandem Duplication of a Large Chromosomal Region. Front Plant Sci. 12; 7: 648. doi:10.3389/fpls.2016.00648. PMID:27242849.

[2] Hollingshead, S., Kopecná, J., Jackson, P. J., Canniffe, D. P., Davison, P. A., Dickman, M. J., Sobotka, R., Hunter, C. N. 2012. Conserved chloroplast open-reading frame ycf54 is required for activity of the magnesium protoporphyrin monomethylester oxidative cyclase in Synechocystis PCC 6803. J Biol Chem. 287(33): 27823-33. doi:10.1074/jbc.M112.352526. PMID: 22711541.

[3] Chidgey, J.W., Linhartová, M., Komenda, J., Jackson, P.J., Dickman, M.J., Canniffe, D.P., Koník, P., Pilný, J., Hunter, C.N., Sobotka, R. 2014. A cyanobacterial chlorophyll synthase-HliD complex associates with the Ycf39 protein and the YidC/Alb3 insertase. Plant Cell. 26(3): 1267-79. doi:10.1105/tpc.114.124495. PMID:24681617.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Cell pellets were dried and immediately extracted with 400 µL of a cold extraction medium MeOH:ACN:H2O (2:2:1 v/v/v) containing an internal standard, 4-fluorophenylalanine (80 nmol). The sample was then homogenized using a Tissue Lyser II (Qiagen) at 50 Hz, 0 °C for 5 min. The mixture was then centrifuged (8000 x g, 10 min, 5 °C). The supernatant was removed, and the extraction step was repeated under the same conditions but without the internal standard. The supernatants were combined and the obtained sample extract stored (-80 °C). A 100 μL aliquot of each extract was mixed with 13C-labeled internal standards (13C3-Serine, 13C3-Alanine, 13C6-Tyrosine, 13C2-Glutamic acid, 13C6-Arginine, 13C6-Lysine, 13C6-Phenylalanine, 13C4-Asparagine, 13C5-Methionine, 13C2-Threonine, 13C4-2-Oxoglutarate, 13C5-Glutamine, 13C5-Proline, 13C6-Arginine, in a absolute concentration of 2 nmol each) and concentrated in a vacuum concentrator (RVC 2-25 CD Plus combined with ALPHA 1-2 LD Plus, Thermo-Fischer Scientific). Each dried extract sample was then subjected to derivatization with ethanol (EtOH) - ethyl chloroformate (ECF) reaction medium, under pyridine catalysis and simultaneous liquid-liquid microextraction into a lower chloroform layer as previously described[1]. Briefly, the following 5 sequential steps were used for the addition of a corresponding medium to the evaporated sample extract: 1) 50 μL of EtOH:H2O(2:1, v/v), 2) 50 μL of EtOH:pyridine (2:1, v/v), 3) 50 μL of ECF:chloroform (1:7, v/v), 4) 50 μL of 1 M NaOH and 5) 50 μL of ECF:chloroform (1:7, v/v). The reaction mixture was stirred before addition of each solvent mix. Finally, 30 μL of the lower chloroform layer was evaporated by a gentle stream of nitrogen and redissolved in 100 μL MeOH:H2O (3:7, v/v) for LC-MS analysis. After this, 50 μL of 1 M HCl was added to the remaining reaction mixture and stirred. Then, 50 μL of the lower chloroform phase was used for GC-MS analysis.


Ref:

[1] Opekar S, Kvíčala J, Moos M, Pejchal V, Šimek P. 2021. Mechanism of Alkyl Chloroformate-Mediated Esterification of Carboxylic Acids in Aqueous Media. J Org Chem. 86(23): 16293-16299. doi:10.1021/acs.joc.1c01546. PMID:34546734.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description:
LC-MS

An Accela 600 liquid chromatograph (LC) and a Accela autosampler (Thermo Fisher Scientific) were used for quantitative analysis. Amino acids were separated on a Kinetex C18 (2.6 µm, 3 mm x 150 mm; Phenomenex), with a mobile phase flow rate of 400 μL/min, an injection volume of 5 μL, and a column temperature of 35 °C. Mobile phase A was: 5 mmol/L ammonium format in methanol and mobile phase B: 5 mmol/L aqueous ammonium format. The gradient used was as follows: 0.0 min, 30% A; 10.0 min, 100% A; 11.0 min, 100% A; 11.1 min, 30% A; 14.5 min, 30% A.


GC-MS

Analysis of amino acids were performed using a gas chromatograph Agilent 5977B MSD and a VF-17ms (0.25 µm, 0.25 mm x 30 m; Varian) capillary column. The instrument settings were: Helium flow rate, 1.2 mL/min; inlet temperature, 280 °C; injection mode, splitless; split flow, 40 mL/min; splitless time, 1.0 min; septum purge flow 3 mL/min; temperature program, 45 °C, hold for 2 min, 16 °C/min to 320 °C, hold for 2 min; transfer line temperature, 280 °C.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description:
LC-MS

An Thermo Scientific LTQ XL linear ion trap mass spectrometer was used for quantitative analysis. Full scan positive ion mass spectra were acquired in a mass range of 85-850 Da. LTQ settings were as follows: ion source parameters, 2.5 kV spray voltage, 300 °C capillary temperature, sheath gas at 40 au, aux gas at 10 au, spare gas at 1 au, source temperature 300 °C.


GC-MS

Analysis were performed using the quadrupole mass spectrometer Agilent 5977B MSD with an electron ionization source (EI) operated in full-scan mode (range 40-500 Da). The instrument settings were: transfer line temperature, 280 °C; EI source temperature, 230 °C; ionization energy, 70 eV.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
LC-MS data were processed using Thermo Xcalibur software version 4.0 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, RRID:SCR_014593).


For GC-MS, data were processed using Agilent MassHunter WorkStation - Qualitative Analysis for GC/MS (Agilent, RRID:SCR_016657) and Agilent Masshunter Quantitative Analysis software version 10 (Agilent, RRID:SCR_015040).

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description: All quantified metabolites were identified by mass and retention time steps with the respective metabolite standard. The external calibration curve method was used for quantification with 13C-labeled internal standards (13C3-Serine, 13C3-Alanine, 13C6-Tyrosine, 13C2-Glutamic acid, 13C6-Arginine, 13C6-Lysine, 13C6-Phenylalanine, 13C4-Asparagine, 13C5 -Methionine, 13C2-Threonine, 13C4-2-Oxoglutarate, 13C5-Glutamine, 13C5-Proline, 13C6-Arginine).
